Description: Neck and shoulder sherd of small Clazomenian black-figured pottery neck-amphora; ridging inside and out at join of neck and shoulder; exterior: neck and ridge black; on shoulder, panel with black border in handle area to left; black-figure decoration consisting of three bearded men to right (head and shoulders of two figures and upper part of head of third; hair and beards in added red and fillets decorated with dots in added white).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For a parallel regarding the beards, see Boston 86.572. The fabric of the sherd was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA) found great similarities with the fabric from Wild Goat Style sherds found at Bayrakli in Asia Minor, production of which Dupont had attributed to Clazomenae. Based on the similar composition types, Dupont then suggested that the place of production for this sherd ought to be situated near Clazomenae, Erythrae, or Teos (Jones with J. Boardman in Jones 1986, p.664).
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 131, no. 15)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 87, pl. X, no. 11)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.010) (Phase 1)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.663, pl.8.12; p.701, table 8.18, no.26)
Hogarth, Lorimer & Edgar 1905 / Naukratis 1903 (p. 121, pl. V, no. 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
